title: How to import survey data
text: first step obtain SAS data file like import. example, use file called namcs2019_sas.sas7bdat. SAS data file National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NAMCS) 2019 Public Use File (PUF). information, location SAS data file can downloaded, see nchsdata::namcs2019.

title: How to import survey data
text: Next, need create SAS formats data file. SAS data file information formats; confused SAS catalog file. formats data file generated SAS using PROC FORMAT command CNTLOUT option, follows: SAS saves formats data file folder specified LIBNAME command.
code: LIBNAME project 'c:\output'; PROC FORMAT CNTLOUT=project.formats_dataset;    VALUE AGERF           1 ='Under 15 years'        2 ='15-24 years'        3 ='25-44 years'        4 ='45-64 years'        5 ='65-74 years'        6 ='75 years and over' ; /* ... */ RUN;

title: How to import survey data
text: importsurvey, several functions named import_sas_*. See functions specifically designed importing survey another survey survey design variables. see available function: Since trying import NAMCS 2019 PUF, notice function called import_sas_namcs2019puf. check help function, see exactly correct function use. import_sas_namcs2019puf can used import NAMCS 2019 PUF survey survey design variables. example, function can used import another survey, called NHAMCS ED 2020 PUF. (info survey, see nchsdata::ed2020.) specialized function already exist, cover scenario .

title: How to import survey data
text: Specify following information: SAS survey data file SAS formats data file name .rds file created. file can read later readRDS(). short name survey survey name, specified label argument, important. used functions surveytable package allow user verify analyzing correct survey. command likely print messages list certain kinds variables. Check messages see whether anything unexpected, indicate mistake. Variables format. intend variables format? list, expect see survey design variables (PATWT) numeric variables (NUMMED). Format applies values, created multiple version variable. numeric variables contain actual values well certain “special values”, often indicate kind missingness. example, consider BMI (body mass index) variable. observations actual value BMI, 25, observations “special value”, one following: -9, meaning “Missing data”; -7, meaning “calculated”; -5, meaning “Height weight outside acceptable ranges”. importsurvey encounters variable, addition original variable, creates two variables, follows. analyst use version variable appropriate specific analysis. X.nospecial: numeric variable values specified formats converted missing values (NA) – “non-special” values retained; X.special: factor variable values specified formats given value “”. (BMI, categorical variable, categories “Missing data”, “calculated”, “Height weight outside acceptable ranges”, “”.) Thus, BMI, one generally use BMI variable directly, contains values BMI well special values. BMI.nospecial used numeric calculations, calculate mean known values. BMI.special used calculate percentages special values. Yes/variable - converted logical. variables converted logical variables, values TRUE, FALSE, NA. can used logical expressions, makes using data easier. example, select visits expected source payment Medicare Medicaid, instead typing PAYMCARE == "Yes" & PAYMCAID == "Yes" one needs type PAYMCARE & PAYMCAID. Many category values used - possible error. Many category values used. done purpose? addition checking messages, please verify survey design variables correct.

title: How to import survey data
text: Load survey just imported, check basic estimates, see make sense. survey design object. can analyzed using survey surveytable packages. Verify survey name, survey design variables, number observations. estimate total seem correct? Total {NAMCS 2019 PUF} estimates couple basic variables seem correct? Patient age recode {NAMCS 2019 PUF} Patient sex {NAMCS 2019 PUF}
code: mysurvey = readRDS("namcs_2019_puf.rds") class(mysurvey) #> [1] "survey.design2" "survey.design" library(surveytable) set_survey("mysurvey") #>                        _              #> Survey name            NAMCS 2019 PUF #> Number of variables    1100           #> Number of observations 8250           #> Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) #> With (398) clusters. #> svydesign(ids = ~CPSUM, strata = ~CSTRATM, weights = ~PATWT,  #>     data = d1) #> * To adjust how counts are rounded, see ?set_count_int total() tab("AGER", "SEX")

what: What if a specialized import function does not exist?
title: How to import survey data
text: specialized import function survey data exist? importsurvey package, import_sas_* functions just short functions call function called import_sas(). See import_sas_* functions written, try issue similar commands survey trying import. import_sas_* functions 3 main steps, follows: Call import_sas() convert SAS survey data file data frame survey data. Schematically, SAS -> data.frame. Call survey::svydesign() convert data frame survey design object. Schematically, data.frame -> survey.design. Label survey design object, save RDS file. example, let’s examine import_sas_namcs2019puf try identify 3 steps. Please sure read help import_sas(). couple important issues keep mind calling import_sas(). Converting Yes/variables logical variables. optional step. need , makes working survey easier. variable levels listed bool_levels argument converted logical variable. default, bool_levels = c("yes", "") RCC SU survey, involved value appropriate, namely, c("yes", "selected", "", "selected", "missing"). bool_true: values, set TRUE? default, bool_true = "yes". RCC SU survey, bool_true = c("yes", "selected"). Likewise, bool_false tells us values set FALSE. default, bool_false = "". RCC SU survey, bool_false = c("", "selected"). values bool_levels bool_true bool_false set NA (missing). Thus, RCC SU, “missing” set NA. Pairing variables formats. tell import_sas() formats go variables. formats argument. formats = "attr": variable data file attribute called format.sas name SAS format. used importing NAMCS survey. formats = "name": variable name format name . used importing RCC survey. formats = "funcname": specify function formats_func argument. function takes variable name returns format name. used importing RCC SU survey. RCC SU, formats_func = function(name) toupper(paste0(name, "f")). , variable name sex, format name SEXF.
code: importsurvey::import_sas_namcs2019puf #> function (sas_data, sas_formats_data, r_out, label = "")  #> { #>     assert_that(!file.exists(r_out), msg = paste0("Output file ",  #>         r_out, " already exists.")) #>     assert_that(is.string(label), nzchar(label)) #>     d1 = import_sas(sas_data, sas_formats_data, formats = "attr",  #>         bool_levels = c("yes", "no"), bool_true = "yes", bool_false = "no",  #>         keep_unformatted = c("DIAG1", "DIAG2", "DIAG3", "DIAG4",  #>             "DIAG5")) #>     sdo = svydesign(ids = ~CPSUM, strata = ~CSTRATM, weights = ~PATWT,  #>         data = d1) #>     attr(sdo, "label") = label #>     attr(sdo$call, "srcref") = NULL #>     message("\n*** Please verify that the correct survey design variables are used (ids, strata, weights, fpc, etc.): ") #>     print(sdo) #>     saveRDS(sdo, r_out) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x0000000018c84688> #> <environment: namespace:importsurvey>

text: Import SAS data R

title: Import SAS data into R — import_sas
code: import_sas(   sas_data,   sas_formats_data,   formats,   bool_levels = c("yes", "no"),   bool_true = "yes",   bool_false = "no",   formats_func = NULL,   keep_unformatted = NULL )

title: Import SAS data into R — import_sas
text: sas_data SAS survey data file sas_formats_data SAS formats data file (produced CNTLOUT option PROC FORMAT) formats formats specified? bool_levels variables levels converted factor (categorical) logical bool_true level(s) variables set TRUE bool_false level(s) variables set FALSE formats_func needed formats = "funcname" keep_unformatted vector variable names. Create unformatted versions variables. argument formats determines formats specified: "attr": attr(*, "format.sas") "name": variable name "funcname": formats_func("x") function returns format name variable "x" Levels bool_levels neither bool_true bool_false set NA.
